news uk-news uk-weather-sub-zero-freeze-"UK Weather: Forecast for Sunday th JanuaryByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsIce-cold temperatures will hover around freezing point this week as severe cold paves way for a snow blast at the end of the month. Met Officer forecasters see the mercury plunging to lows of -C over the next seven days with the chill remaining in the low single-digits every night and reaching just over the C mark in daylight hours. The freezing conditions will lead the way for snowfall, which looks set to blast some regions of the isles on Friday, January . WXCharter meteorologists say snow will be first seen in Scotland before moving south to northern England, according to the Sun Online.East Anglia is predicted to be hit with wintry showers early on January , before parts of the country between Aberdeen and Hampshire will then see snow on Sunday January .  The looming arctic chill follows the trend of recent days after the Met Office warned of -C conditions amid blanketings of thick icy fog on Friday. Daylight hours this week will see milder temperatures, reaching as high as C in the southwest while generally staying around the  or C mark. But as night approaches the cold will take hold with bone-shaking chills of -C seen in Wales on the coldest night of the week, which looks set to be the early hours of Tuesday morning.  Birmingham and London look set for lows of C on that freezing morning as Swindon plunges to freezing point. Temperatures in the east of England will struggle to stay over the zero mark, with C conditions likely. This cold front will be seen all the way up the east coast, hitting York and Newcastle upon Tyne. Today, Brits in Scotland and Northern Ireland will be able to bask in some winter sun as conditions stay generally dry across the UK, but with some chance of rain in the far south of England and central UK this afternoon.  The cold snap will arrive tonight with noticeably chillier conditions that will lead to widespread frost by tomorrow morning. Monday will start cold, but be generally dry with the chance of rain in the very far north.Last Friday, the Met Office urged everyone to get the hot water bottles at the ready as itaposs set to be a cold and frosty night amid reports of brutally cold -C night ahead.Despite temperatures plummeting, Brits shouldnapost expect any snow yet. MET OFFICE OUTLOOK Today: Sunny spells today, best of the sunshine across Scotland and Northern Ireland. Dry for many but some early showery rain in the far south and a little rain at times for northern England this morning and central UK this afternoon. Tonight: Most areas dry with long clear periods and fog patches. Cloudier and windier in the far north with some rain at times. Colder than last night with widespread frost. Monday: A chilly start then most areas fine, dry and bright with plenty of sunshine once early fog patches clear. Cloudier in the very far north with rain at times. Outlook for Tuesday to Thursday: A cold and foggy start for some on Tuesday, with sunny spells developing. Rain arrives into the northwest later, sinking south but weakening through Wednesday. Thursday, dry with sunny spells.Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Met OfficeSnowWeather" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: man reviews biggest tea brands
story: Man reviews biggest tea brands in UK - and announces an unlikely winnerLewis Smith, journalist for Wales Online, decided to settle one of the nations great debates and find out which brand of tea is the best of them all - and his verdict might upset one or two peopleLewis reviewed each of the most popular tea brands in the UK Image: Lewis SmithByLewis SmithJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsItaposs the nationaposs favourite drink by a long way, with nothing quite so British as waking up to a nice cuppa to start the day off right.We Brits love our tea, with a good old mug of English breakfast being our favourite type as boxes of the stuff sit in kitchens up and down the UK. But with so many dferent brands to choose from, sometimes itaposs impossible to know which type to go for in the supermarket. Luckily, a reporter for Wales Online has done the heavy lting for the rest of us, sitting down to a proper tea tasting test to determine the best brand. Reporter Lewis Smith sat down with six brands: Tetley, Twinings, Yorkshire Tea, PG Tips, Tesco Original and a special Welsh blend, Paned Gymreig.  For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Using ml of water and a splash of milk in each cup, Lewis judged the taste of each brew to figure out which was best. First sitting down with a mug of Paned Gymreig, Lewis noted its rich taste and golden brown flavour. Despite a fairly satisfying taste test, he admitted it didnapost blow me away, and gave it a respectable .  rating. Next Lewis sat down with a slightly more expensive brand, Twinings Everyday. But, despite the fact it could be described as premium, Lewis was underwhelmed by the taste of the cuppa and decided some of the cheaper brands were much tastier. Bearing in mind price versus taste, Lewis gave it an unimpressive rating of  . Next up was PG Tips, a well known and moderately priced teabag that is a firm favourite in many households. He noted the lovely smell that greeted him as he opened the box of teabags, and said the taste lived up to the aroma. After admitting he could sit around and drink PG Tips all day, he gave the brand  . His fourth cuppa was a mugful of Yorkshire Tea - which could be argued to be the most popular brand of tea in the UK.  But Lewisaposs verdict will leave many fans of the northern brew upset, as he gave it a measly rating of . . Explaining his reasoning, Lewis said: It was one of my least favourite drinks due to the uniquely robust flavour that was not to my preference. He did admit, however, that the cup of Yorkshire Tea looked more appealing than most others he tested. Cuppa number five was a blend of Tesco Original, which came in at a bargain price - and Lewis reckoned he got more than enough for his money. Describing the cuppa as incredibly light and rich, he said it was another brew he could sit and drink all day. In what could be a surprising verdict for many, he gave the Tesco cuppa a rating of . . Finally, Lewis poured himself a cup of Tetley tea, another firm UK favourite that has been on the shelves since . Describing Tetley as his previous go-to choice for a brew, he realised on this taste test that it didnapost offer the same quality of flavour heaposd had from the PG Tips and Tesco options. Still, he offered it a respectable . . After sitting down with each cuppa, Lewis was adamant that Tesco Original was his favourite cuppa - closely followed by PG Tips. As for family favourites like Yorkshire Tea and Twinings, he could take or leave them - which is likely to ide Brits around the country. title: mum left mortified after accidentally
story: Mum left mortied after accidentally sending son to school with worst lunch everA mum was left in hysterics when she realised shed given her son the wrong packed lunch. She shared the blunder on Mumsnet where users shared stories of their own Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsThereaposs no such thing as a perfect parent. With one hundred and one tasks to tackle, itaposs inevitable that there are slip-ups along the way - as one mum found out. A woman was left in hysterics after she made the honest mistake of giving her son the wrong packed lunch.The woman took to Mumsnet to share the hilarious blunder, where she explained she was supposed to give her son pasta salad for his packed lunch.But it was when he asked why sheaposd given him funny mashed potato instead, she realised her mistake. Taking to the parenting site, she wrote: I told DS [darling son] he had pasta salad for lunch, she said. This evening he asked why we’d given him aposfunny mashed potatoapos instead. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Turns out the pasta salad was still in the fridge and he’d been eating a tub full of fat I’d saved for the birds. Has anyone sent their child to school with anything worse or are we officially the worst parents on Mumsnet  she concluded her post. One person said: No, but this made me laugh out loud after a busy day! How much of it did he eat ! Ahahahahahaha!!!! Oh dear, said another. A third laughed: Iaposm surprised you didnapost get a confused call from the school receptionist!! Someone  said: Crying with laughter here - you definitely win the award for the worst packed lunch ever. Others shared funny stories of their own. We sent our son to school with a tub of margarine once, said one woman. Another added: My brother once opened his lunchbox at school to find therein a banana that was past its best covered in biscuit crumbs. Brother was only very little at the time so a banana and a few biscuits might havebeen an adequate lunch as a one-off. But the biscuits didn’t survive the journey being swung about by a -year-old, so a crumb-coated banana was lunch that day. A third then said: I had a bit of a rep for sending my kids to school with sandwiches made from mouldy bread.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. news weird-news my-boyfriend-said-wear-makeup-"Tiktok - Xlily.brownxByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsA woman was left feeling sick after her boyfriend told her she needed to wear makeup to make a good first impression on his friends.Taking to TikTok Lily Brown @xlily.brownxexplained how she had plans to meet her boyfriendaposs friends for the first time.Thinking it was casual she hadnapost dressed up or put any makeup on, but her boyfriend was less than impressed. In a video that has been viewed . million times, she shared the shocking text exchange between the pair, with the caption: Here’s to being single in . Lily’s boyfriend at the time started off the conversation with a message saying: Hey hey babe, have you started getting ready for tonight yet  to which Lily replied with: Yeah I’m ready now. Ooh can I see gorgeous  he asked her. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Lily responded with: I haven’t done makeup or anything for tonight, it’s just casual right  But her boyfriend replied saying: Yeah babe but do you mind just popping a little bit on as you are meeting my mates and stuff for the first time. At this point, Lily was thinking ‘he’s joking, right ’. Don’t want them thinking I’ve pulled a clapped one, he had the cheek to say. Shocked she said: My bf did not just call me CLAPPED. Trying to justy the comment, he said: first impressions and that but the damage had already been done. Now I don’t want to go because you’ve made me feel bad about it, she told him. But instead of apologising and trying to fix things, he got agitated and told her not to come. Ugh babe don’t bother then, either put something on your face or don’t turn up because I cba. Heartbroken, she asked TikTok: Why do I always end up with toxic men  Lily later revealed that she dumped her boyfriend after receiving these messages. Since being posted, the video has racked up more than , likes and almost , comments from viewers who were stunned by his replies. One person said: When I tell you this boy wouldaposve received the SWIFTEST block. Another wrote: AS SOON AS I SAW CLAPPED I GASPED. A third commented: Ainapost no way he thought it was okay to say that. Someone  said: And that sir is how you end a relationship in three seconds.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. news weird-news school-receptionist-brutally-roasts-kids-"TikTok user reveals what she thinks of children’s namesByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsPicking a name for your baby is one of the first, and perhaps most dficult, decisions a parent will have to make. They say that your name influences the sort of person you will become, which is why itaposs so important to take your time whittling down your list before picking one for your own child. But before you make your choice, a school reception worker has shared her brutal opinion on what your kidsapos names really mean - and she didnapost hold back.Manda Dee, who is best known as @theschoolofficelady on TikTok, has posted a series of videos on the names she likes and dislikes.First up for the boys was Liam - but it also applies to any boy with an aposL name.apos Your child cries... cries a lot and those tears arenapost real, she said. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Boys called Jack got off lightly as she called them incredibly hyperactive and crazy. Hayden is running someoneaposs le. I donapost knowit is the teacheraposs or yours - youaposve gotta tone it down, youaposve gotta stop spoiling that child. Then she roasts the name, Rex. You thought it was it was like a dogsapos name so you thought he was going to be happy-go-lucky, she started. Heaposs overly opinionated and he inserts his comments when they arenapost necessary. Tone it down. Next up was Xavier, as she said: I donapost knowheaposs not listening or he just canapost hear me. Xander was also met with criticism. I donapost know how to say this, she said. You thought Xander was going to be a girl. He wasnapost... he was another boy. She said boys named Emmitt never listen to their mums, Jadens try to kiss girls in the years above and those named Elijah donapost take part in group work because theyaposre too busy talking to their teachers about the show Dr Phil and basketball. Isaac or any less common bible names like Cain, Abel and Caleb,a first-grade classes Legos are missing, theyaposre probably in his pockets, she said. And finally we have Daniel. Daniel left his coat in the playground again and probably one of his shoes. Then it was time for her to judge the girls names. Girls called Lexi are sneaky, so sneaky, while Paisley is super cute... from far away. But sheaposs a hot mess. Olivia youaposre a sweetheart now, but youaposre gonna be a b***h once you get to high school, she said. Penelope is so cute but sheaposs left her bear at the resort again and youaposve got to drive back four hours and get it. She is so forgetful. Sheaposs the Daniel of girls. But she didnapost stop there. Hazel, Ruth, Evelyn, Lilith, basically all of the old, old lady names, you need to stop correcting me child and your mum needs a nice glass of wine and a long walk in the sunshine. She added: Any name that implies innocence - Heaven, Angel, Purity, Charity - your child is the opposite, your child is the devil. But what does she think about Sophies and Sophias  Manda said theyaposre often the cutest, nicest, smartest girls until they get into trouble, they stab their friends in the back and throw everyone under the bus. Charlotte. Be sure to check Charlotteaposs backpack before she gets to class today because itaposs likely thereaposs a dead bird in there that she found on the way to school, Manda declared. Ava is definitely the Isaiah of the girl names. Sheaposs so cute but sheaposs such a liar. Manda explained that Amanda will spill their sisteraposs nail polish on the classroom rug and will blame it on another kid. Isabella refuses to wear her sneakers to gym, instead she wants to wear her Ana and Elsa sparkly jelly flats.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. news weird-news tiktok-chefs-master-formula-perfect-"TikTok chef shares how to make homemade Nando’s burger for just £ByRia NewmanJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsNandoaposs is is a firm favourite among many Brits whether itaposs for a family meal, a quick pre-cinema dinner or even a cosy takeaway. And when the craving for Peri Peri chicken rears its head, nothing  quite his the spot. In recent years, Nandoaposs has even started selling its own-brand sauces, mayonnaise and other items in supermarkets so fans can recreate their recipes at home. But even armed with a bottle of hot Peri Peri sauce, you need the know-how to create a decent homage to Nandoaposs classics like their wraps or burgers. Luckily, a TikTok chef has figured out the exact recipe for putting together the Nandoaposs burger from the comfort of your own kitchen - and itaposll only set you back £, a fraction of the price of the real thing.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Bartek, , from London, insists his formula for the perfect Nandoaposs burger is even better than the real thing. The former bartender shot to fame on TikTok after learning how to cook during lockdown when he wasnapost able to work. Now he shares his unique recipes in videos, which have earned him thousands of followers on the . In order to recreate his chicken burger, he uses a burger bun made of garlic bread. He then tops it with homemade perinaise - a mixture of peri peri sauce and mayonnaise. On top of that is the salad of lettuce and tomatoes, before two peri peri chicken thighs which have been chargrilled. Even including an extra that would set you back a few quid in Nandoaposs, he adds grilled halloumi to the top of the burger before topping it all off with another slice of garlic bread. title: ufo spotter makes sighting earths
story: UFO spotter makes sighting in Earths orbit thats  per cent proofA UFO reportedly several times bigger than the International Space Station has been caught on camera and the sighting is " per cent proof that aliens are watching over Earth"A man believes he has found irrefutable evidence of an alien spaceship visiting earth Image: ufosightingsdailyByJohn BettAudience WriterCharles Wade-PalmerReporter:,  Jan | comments A UFO spotter says he has found  per cent proof that aliens are watching over Earth after a picture of the International Space Station was shared online. Scott Waring is a space buff and runs the website UFO Sightings Daily, and there he shared a blown-up version of the image where you could see a reddish object that he claims is an alien spacecraft. He said that after careful analysis, he was sure it wasnapost the moon, and whatever it was it was much, much larger than the ISS in the foreground, as the Daily Star reports.Scott said that he monitors the space stationaposs live stream and has done for the past six years, so he knows a rare sighting when he sees one. What do you think of Scottaposs sighting  Let us know in the comments...Publishing his find on Wednesday, stunned Scott said: Watch this live space station footage taken today and you will see a close up of a huge sphere UFO rising up in earths orbit. Itaposs not the moon. The moon is five times bigger and bright. This object is much smaller, oval in shape and has some unique red green colours to it. The teacher from Taiwan believes there is no other explanation for what was picked up on camera, other than an extraterrestrial controlled spaceship.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. Scott told his , readers: I and others have seen such UFOs orbiting Earths moon, but this event is a very rare one to see orbiting Earth. This UFO is several times bigger than the space station. Absolutely amazing catch and  per cent proof that aliens are watching over Earth. Scott recently thanked his audience for donating to his fundraiser so he could afford a brand new computer capable of meeting his UFO detective demands.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. news weird-news woman-mocks-date-how-eats-"Woman films date eating salad with his fingersByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsFirst dates are always a daunting experience. Sometimes they go great and other times... not so great. Such was the case for one woman, as her dateaposs eating habits left her cringed out. Sydney Kinney, from Iowa, was looking forward to her date with a guy she met on Tider, and all seemed to be going well until it was time to eat the main course. As she tucked into her dish, she looked over to her date and saw he was eating his salad with his hands.She posted a video of the man tucking into his meal on her TikTok @sydkinnn, where she said: I met this guy on Tinder and decided to go on a date with him. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. “This is how he ate his salad. Since being posted, the video has been liked more than , times and has received , comments from ided viewers, many of whom were shocked to see him eating with his fingers. One person said: I broke up with a guy before because my toddler ate better than him. Another wrote: Immediately no. A third commented: Oh gosh, boy bye. Someone : He’s not eating, he’s shovelling. Goodbye. However, a few people defended the guy and said she was a red flag for mocking and exposing him online. And  Whataposs the problem  asked one person. Another said: Red flag. Others informed her that itaposs common in some cultures to eat with your hands. He’s being himself plus some cultures eat with their hands, they wrote. Sydney later posted another video with the guy after giving him another chance, and was seen eating at a Mexican restaurant. More recent videos show Sydney calling the man her boyfriend, so it seems his eating habits didnapost scare her away.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: woman praises 69p aldi tea
story: Woman praises p Aldi tea for giving her the best sleep shes had in agesA woman struggling to sleep took to Facebook to share a wonderous tea she found in Aldi that gave her the best night sleep shed had in ages Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsWeaposve all struggled to drop off to sleep at one point or another. Whether itaposs a busy mind keeping you up or your phone, there are plenty of things you can try to successfully send you into the land of nod - like drinking herbal tea. One woman swears by the remedy and says that it has completely transformed her night.Lindsay says she tried Aldiaposs Diplomat Night Time tea to see whether it would help her drt off to sleep, and when she woke in the morning she was thrilled by how well sheaposd slept. She posted about the le-saving tea in the Aldi UK shoppers group on Facebook, and said: Best nights sleep Iaposve had in ages after this sleep tea.For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. But Lindsey wasnapost the only one to speak highly of the tea as many others shared their positive testimonials on her post. One person said: Iaposve been taking the sleep one since  days ago and honestly it works better than sleeping pills and also works on my anxiety levels so I drink a cup here and then during the day....and the taste is lovely too!! Another wrote: I use the Twinnings one but will definitely be swapping to these saving £ a box. Thanks for sharing. A third wrote: I tried it last night and slept great. Could have been four nights of tossing and turning but Iaposm saying it was the tea. But not everyone was convinced by its sleep benefits as one person said although it tastes lovely it left her tired the next morning. They wrote: So I had this last night thinking it was going to be a miracle cure for my restless nights! Not sureI was fighting against it trying to prove it wrong or what. But I had the worst night ever! Soooo tired this morning. But I will give it the benefit of doubt and stick with it! I will either be a walking zombie by next weekend or I will be full of beans! Time will tell! On a plus note, it tastes lovely! The tea is flavoured with chamomile which is often thought to have calming properties. The full list of ingredients include: Flowering Tops , Chamomile Flowers , Liquorice Root , Lavender Flowers, Lime Flower, Tulsi Leaf, and Valerian Root. Aldi does warn that anyone suffering from hypertension should avoid the tea as it contains liquorice. And itaposs easy enough to whip up. Simply pour freshly boiled water over the teabag and leave for three minutes for it to do its thing. But one woman says to get the full benefits, you should use two teabags. You can purchase a box of  teabags for just p in the superstore. The Diplomat Sleep Tea is part of a new Aldi range with other options claiming to boost the immune system, help with digestion, and even give you a detox.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: woman texts date next day
story: Woman texts date next day to thank him - then realises hes still in the houseA woman who had one too many beers on a date woke up the next morning to thank him for a lovely evening - but his response took her by surprise and left her red-facedZoes funny story resonated with a lot of people Image: TikTok   @zoechappersByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsThe dating scene can be pretty tough in the age of apps and social media - but it can give people some brilliant stories to tell.Whether itaposs something theyaposve done to make themselves look foolish, or something youaposve said that you instantly regretted, the world of dating is turbulent, to say the least.But one TikToker who had a hilarious date - or rather, day after her date - has shared her funny story with followers after being left red-faced and in shock. After a Tinder date with a man which had gone well and left her with a sore head from one too many drinks, Zoe Chaplin sent her companion a text the morning after the date to thank him for a lovely evening. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here But his reply gave her a shock - as it had been sent from the next room. She captioned the video: When I had a tinder date stay over  got so drunk I text him saying thanks for a good night and he replies I’m still on your sofa, I put you to bed. After sharing her embarrassment with viewers, they were quick to praise her date for sleeping on the sofa and making sure she was safely in bed. In response, Zoe said: Not many men would do the same. But in another comment she added: So embarrassing going down stairs to him on the sofa. People were keen to find outthis decent man and Zoe had gone the distance, and askedthe pair had had a second date. Zoe wrote: This was a while ago, we dated for a bit but we went our separate ways in the end. Lots of people viewing the video saw themselves in Zoeaposs story, and reckoned it was something theyaposd do on a date. One person wrote: My kinda night, to which Zoe replied: Too much wine! title: mum 24 sheds 6st military
story: Mum, , sheds st with military workout regime after eating McDonalds every dayMum-of-one Alex Moore, , from Adelaide in Australia, gained five-and-a-half stone while pregnant with daughter Alora and found herself eating from fast food joint McDonalds "at least" once a day for four monthsAlex Moore, , stacked on the weight during her pregnancy and would eat McDonalds at least once a day Image: Jam Press @alexpaigemooreByOlivia Loveridge-GreenRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A mum who ate McDonaldaposs at least once a day during her pregnancy has lost an incredible six stone – thanks to a gruelling military-style workout regime.Alex Moore, , from Adelaide, Australia, gained five-and-a-half stone while pregnant with her daughter Alora, now -months-old.Fed up with her “mum tum” and weighing st lbs, she decided to get in shape, swapping burgers for protein-rich meals. Following what she calls a strict military regime – which saw her take daily am visits to the gym and embark on km walks, working out for two-and-a-half hours a day – the mum-of-one managed to shed six stone in nine months.Despite being in better physical shape than before she had children, Alex says her meals are now bigger than what they were before – but packed with nutritious ingredients. She found out she was pregnant at the end of  and says midway through her pregnancy she began to eat unhealthily, causing her to pile on the pounds. “I really stacked on the weight – I was working long hours as a dental nurse and would eat McDonaldaposs at least once a day,” Alex, a former dental nurse, said.  I was starting early I’d usually get hash brown, egg and bacon muffin and hot chocolate for breakfast. And then for lunch I’d order a Quarter Pounder or Big Mac meal, a chocolate sundae and extra chicken nuggets with mayo. My mental health throughout most of my pregnancy was fine, however I did struggle towards the end realising how much weight I had gained and not recognising myself.” Alex welcomed her daughter in May  – but found herself feeling uncomfortable with her body. She said: I didnapost want to go out anywhere to show her off, I just wanted to hide away. I felt guilty Iaposd given birth to a beautul baby girl but I was so embarrassed about how I looked so never wanted my picture taken with her. I constantly heard was aposyour body will never be the sameapos and aposyou will always have a mum tum, learn to love itapos.  I didnapost want to be like that, so I used it as motivation. Alex decided that enough was enough and began to get in shape by hitting the gym and overhauling her diet. She said: I worked my a** off at the gym going at am every morning and going for km walks every day. At first I was really strict on my diet. I probably went too hard and developed somewhat of an eating disorder.  Iaposve now worked out a healthy relationship with food and exercise. Before I was only eating three small meals a day. Now I have larger meals and snacks. I donapost really count macros, or calories. I just try to eat mainly whole foods, regularly. I eat three main meals a day and have a snack in the morning which may be a protein bar, protein shake or a bit of fruit. In the afternoon I snack on a yoghurt but I try to listen to my body. I no longer turn down opportunities to eat out, and enjoy treats without guilt.  Alongside her healthy diet, Alex decided to ditch cardio and HIIT workouts in favour of weight training in a bid to gain lean muscle. She has currently shed six stone – and is healthier than ever. Her impressive weight loss has even let Alex change careers, swapping dental nursing for the glamourous le of an OnlyFans model.  She said: I saw it as a good source of income being a single mum having my daughter majority of the time. Now I can spend my days with Alora, and still make a good income. Alex shared a video documenting her weight loss to her , TikTok followers, who showered the mum-of-one with praise. One TikTok user said: This is what hard work and discipline looks like queens! Good job mumma. A second follower added: I literally gasped, this is amazing. Such an amazing transformation. Well done,” said another fan. One inspired viewer commented: Youaposre doing amazing Alex, itaposs empowering watching you.” While someone  said: Yes mama. You look awesome. Speaking about how her journey may inspire others, Alex added: I really want to show other mums what you can achieve when you set goals and are determined enough to achieve them. I also want people to know that itaposs important not to neglect self-care just because youaposre a mother – youaposre allowed to treat yourself and do things just for yourself. news world-news north-korea-accused-cultural-appropriation-"North Korea accused of appropriating Latino cultureByMichael HavisGraeme Murray:,  Jan | commentsNorth Korea has been accused of “appropriating Latino culture” by taking credit for the invention of the burrito. Recent propaganda from the secretive state featured a suspiciously burrito-like dish called a “wheat wrap”, allegedly invented in  by Kim Jong-il – the current leaderaposs father and predecessor. Kim Jong-un was also said to take a “meticulous interest” in the foodstuff, whose popularity was reportedly “booming” in Pyongyang. But now a civil rights group representing Latin Americans has blasted the oppressive regime for the boast, warning “don’t mess with our burritos”. The League of United Latin American Citizens , the largest and oldest Latino civil rights group in the US, said there had been an “explosive reaction” ranging from Texas to Calornia.  “Kim Jong-un is feeding into a delusionhe thinks North Korea can wake up one morning and appropriate our Latino cultural identity,” said LULAC boss Domingo Garcia. “The fact is Mexicans have been building and eating real burritos for hundreds of years.” He continued: “The origin of burritos is steeped deep in our history back to the days of the tamal in the Aztec civilisation.  “The women would place pieces of dried meat inside a moist ball of cornmeal and wrap it in a cornhusk. “In time, the cornmeal masa was replaced by a corn or flour tortilla, which evolved into the modern-day burrito. “You might call it the first take-out food of the Americas.”Mr Garcia rounded off by saying North Korean burritos were no match for the real thing.“Imitation is the best form of flattery,” he said. “But thereaposs no way that a street vendor in Pyongyang who has never even seen a tortilla comal is going to be able to compete with Abuelitaaposs [granny’s] best, made-from-scratch, piping hot burritos. “They look pretty skimpy from the television footage, and real burritos are bursting with all the meat, rice, beans and avocado packed into them. “North Korean and Mexicano burritos aren’t even in the same class.  “Sorry Kim Jong-un, you don’t get a free pass on this one.” The outburst comes after the Kim regime broadcast propaganda showing North Koreans devouring wheat wraps at a stand outside the Kumsong Food Factory in Pyongyang. The broadcast also showed a mural of Kim Jong-il grinning in a kitchen where the burrito-like wraps were being prepared. However there are some dferences between the North Korean dish and its Tex-Mex cousin.  For example, the Pyongyang version seems to contain some kind of doner meat, with what appears to be a mix of cabbage and carrot. Kim Jong-il advised that they are best accompanied by mineral water in the summer and hot tea in the winter, according to North Korea’s Rodong Sinmun newspaper.  The original, meanwhile, typically contains beef, chicken or pork alongside rice, beans and other ingredients. The exact provenance of the modern burrito is unclear, however the word burrito appears in an  Mexican dictionary, where it is described as a foodstuff. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Eveningcontent online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Courier. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Tayside and Fe. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Courier and the Eveningnewspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . title: pioneering-glasgow-doctor-margaret-kerr-saved-lives-hundreds-premature-babies
story: COMPASSIONATE and dedicated, Dr Margaret Kerr’s work in Glasgow saved the lives of hundreds of premature babies. The consultant paediatrician at what was then the Royal Hospital for Sick Children at Yorkhill was a leading light in neo-natal medicine. She once said in an interview with the Evening Times: “I love babies – we are no longer just saving le but producing healthy future citizens. That gives us all pride and pleasure.”

title: farmers face fertiliser price standoff
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: end bedtime story benefits reading children keig aberdeenshire
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: aberdeen detached home walled gardens 460k
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: council votes on aberdeenshire platinum jubilee day off
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: man barricades himself inside aberdeen residence
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits.
